Three quarters of these were members of the Commonwealth.
There was no shortage of people, nor of the
will to work, nor of land to work upon. What they needed was stability, finance, and know-how.
A quarter of the world's people just couldn't be allowed to go on indefinitely living in extreme
poverty. Something had to be done to help. That something became the Colombo Plan. Knowing how closely her destiny is linked with those of South and Southeast Asia,
New Zealand was among the first to offer her services in this cause.
The year was 1950.
Today there are some 20 nations in this Colombo Plan fraternity,
all concerned with the cooperative development of this vast area.
One aspect of New Zealand's share in the Colombo Plan all concerned with the cooperative development of this vast area.
One aspect of New Zealand share in the Colombo plan is the provision of facilities for students from member countries
to learn new skills or to improve on skills already learned.
